Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Undergraduate Research in Collaborative Data Visualization Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds a new CISE REU Site to provide a novel approach to broadening participation in visualization, while accelerating discovery and progress. Visualization plays a significant role in the exploration and understanding of data across all disciplines with a universal goal: gaining insight into the complex relationships that exist within the data. A multi-disciplinary team of faculty and visualization staff plans to establish a site that focuses on research across several domains including Computer Science, Genetics and Biochemistry, Geophysics, Sociology, Molecular Modeling and Simulation, Inorganic Chemistry, Social Media, Parks Recreation Tourism Management, Biological Sciences, and Digital Humanities.

The overall objectives of the REU Site are to broaden participation in visualization, to explore visualization jointly with research projects while accelerating discovery and progress, and to utilize visualization as a conduit for collaboration. The REU Site achieves these objectives by: exploring visualization in parallel with research, involving students directly in data-driven visualization with an interdisciplinary aspect, providing training in tools and technologies that are common in visualization research, inspiring students to consider visualization as a career path and pursue visualization at the graduate level, and targeting participation of women and underrepresented groups, as well as students from institutions with limited cyberinfrastructure resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This REU Site supported by this award enabled three mentored, 8-weeks summer research and training programs for diverse sets of undergraduate students across the nation in the area of visualization. The program, hosted by
Clemson Computing and Information Technology at Clemson University, leveraged Clemson's visualization resources, extensive infrastructure, leading reputation in cyberinfrastructure, and experienced visualization mentoring team with research interests spanning multiple domains created a multidisciplinary research experience for undergraduates. The ratio of participants to applicants were:

  • 2014 (10 out of 26)
  • 2015 (12 out of 205)
  • 2017 (10 out of 230)

The acceptance rate decreased over time, as the popularity of the REU program increased. The site inspired participating students to consider visualization as a career path and pursue visualization at the graduate level. The site targeted participation of women and underrepresented groups. Participants gained hands-on experience with the visualization process and in discerning important relationships that exist in data through analysis and visualization. The outcome of this REU program positively impacted various fields such as Computer Science, Genetics & Biochemistry, Geophysics, Sociology, Molecular Modeling & Simulation, Inorganic Chemistry, Social Media, Parks Recreation & Tourism Management, Environmental Engineering & Earth Sciences, Biological Sciences, Digital Humanities, Electrical & Computer Engineering, Material Sciences, Civil Engineering, Youth Family & Community Studies, Athletics, Geographical Information Systems, and Industrial Engineering.
